I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  Mongolia  for  the  Western  Regional  Road  Corridor 
Investment Program.1
 
 
2. 
The outputs of the investment program will be (i) completion of the western regional road 
(293  km  of  roads  to  be  constructed),  (ii)  three  maintenance  units  established  and  equipped, 
(iii) 34.9  km  of  local  roads  and  three  bridges  rehabilitated  to  connect  provincial  and  district 
centers to the western regional road, and (iv) improved capacity of road institutions.2
 
 

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

Rationale 

A. 
 
3. 
Mongolia is a large, sparsely populated country located between the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) to the south, and the Russian Federation to the north. Due to the large land area, 
low  population  density,  and  severe  weather  conditions  during  winter,  surface  transportation  in 
Mongolia  is  difficult.  Paved  roads  account  for  just  over  5%  of  the  total  road  network  with  the 
majority of roads only dirt tracks. The route of the proposed western regional road corridor, which 
is  part  of  Asian  Highway  4  and  is  designated  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation 
(CAREC)  Corridor  4a,  runs  north–south  from  Mongolia’s  border  with  the  Russian  Federation  at 
Ulaanbayshint to its border with the PRC at Yarant, a total distance of about 743 kilometers (km). 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  supporting  the  development  of  111 km  of  the  corridor 
through the Western Regional Road Corridor Development Project–Phase I (phase I).3
 The PRC 
is financing 145 km of the corridor, while the Government of Mongolia is developing 194 km. The 
remaining 293 km of road is proposed to be developed under the investment program. 
 
Mongolia’s  western  region  suffers  from  slow  development  because  of  its  remoteness 
4. 
from the country’s political and economic centers and its inadequate transport network. Roads 
to  and  within  the  region  are  mostly  unpaved  and  impose  heavy  travel  costs  on  residents  and 
visitors. As a result, the region lacks adequate access to jobs, markets, and social services, and 
is  significantly  poorer  than  other  parts  of  Mongolia.  Gross  domestic  product  per  capita  in  the 
western  region  is  only  75%  of  the  national  average.  The  poverty  incidence  was  48%  in  2008, 
compared with the national average of 34%. Due to their proximity to the PRC and the Russian 
Federation,  Bayan-Olgiy  and  Khovd  provinces  import  about  75%  of  their  energy,  food, 
consumer goods, and construction materials from the two countries. 
 
5. 
Lack of paved roads results in high transport costs and long travel times. The investment 
program is the government’s top priority road investment after the ADB-financed Regional Road 
Development Project.4
 A functioning paved road network will help Mongolia to  link together its 
large  and  poorly  connected  territory  to  promote  social  and  economic  development.  While  the 
western  region  is  sparsely  populated,  it  is  home  to  185,000  people,  who  currently  have  no

 paved road access to regional cities and towns. The investment program will provide a vital link 
to  economic  opportunities  and  social  services,  reduce  the  high  costs  of  imports,  and  improve 
the competitiveness of the region’s export products. 
 
Cross-border  transport.  Mongolia’s western  regional road  corridor can also serve  as a 
6. 
direct and convenient transit route between the Xinjiang  Uygur Autonomous  Region of the PRC 
and  the  Russian  Federation,  reducing  transport  costs  and  facilitating  trade,  tourism,  and  other 
economic  activities.  Rising  incomes  will  increase  the  demand  for  imports  from  neighboring 
countries, which are now constrained due to extremely high transport costs. Efficient cross-border 
transport will be essential for the western regional road to deliver the envisioned benefits. ADB is 
assisting  the  PRC  to  improve  cross-border  transport  in  the  region  through  the  Xinjiang  Altay 
Urban  Infrastructure  and  Environment  Improvement  Project, 6
 which  includes  infrastructure 
improvements at the Takeshiken land port on the PRC side of the border near Yarant. 
 
7. 
Trade  and  regional  transport  is  hindered  by  the  lack  of  cross-border  transport 
agreements.  Mongolia  has  an  existing  cross-border  transport  agreement  with  the  Russian 
Federation  allowing  reciprocal  access  to  each  country’s  vehicles.  In  practice,  Russian  trucks 
rarely  travel  south  of  Olgiy  due  to  the  poor  road  conditions.  On  the  PRC  side,  Mongolian 
vehicles generally cannot travel past Takeshiken, near the border, and vehicles from the PRC 
can  only  travel  to  designated  locations  in  Mongolia;  usually  to  deliver  materials  for  road 
construction.  No  trilateral  transit  system  covers  movements  between  the  PRC,  Mongolia,  and 
the Russian Federation. Given the importance of transit agreements to Mongolia, a component 
on  a  cross-border  road  transport  facilitation  plan  was  included  under  the  Regional  Road 
Development  Project,  which  is  now  under  implementation  (footnote  4).  Further  support  for 
transport and trade facilitation is being provided through regional TA.7
 
 
8. 
Lessons  from  prior  road  projects. Road projects in Mongolia have experienced cost 
overruns  and  delays  in  implementation.  Cost  overruns  were  primarily  the  result  of  large 
worldwide commodity price increases during 2007–2008, and the lack of recent bid prices upon 
which  to  base  road  construction  cost  estimates.  The  Regional  Road  Development  Project 
required  supplementary  financing  in  2008  to  cover  cost  overruns. 8
 The  phase  I  project  has 
likewise  experienced  cost  increases  for  which  the  government  has  requested  additional 
financing  (para.  13).  ADB  has  taken  steps  to  prevent  cost  overruns  under  the  proposed 
investment program through extensive due diligence on the detailed design and cost estimates. 
All  estimates  are  now  based  on  recent  bid  prices  from  the  phase  I  project.  In  addition,  the 
revised cost estimates incorporate large contingencies to account for potential inflation impacts.  
 
9. 
Past implementation delays were caused by problems with (i) preparing bid documents, 
(ii) evaluating  bids,  (iii)  preparing  bid  evaluation  reports,  and  (iv) preparing  acceptable 
withdrawal  applications.  ADB  intends  to  address  the  implementation  problems  with  a  multi-
faceted  capacity  development  effort  that  will  provide  international  consultancy  support  to  the 
government  and  project  implementation  units  (PIUs).  This  will  directly  assist  with,  and  provide 
on-the-job  training  in,  every  aspect  of  procurement,  project  management,  and  implementation 
for the duration of the first tranche implementation period.

 Justification for financing modality. The investment program represents an expansion 
10. 
of over 20% of the entire paved road network in Mongolia, which will require a medium- to long-
term commitment by ADB to assist the government in completing the road corridor. The cost of 
completing  the  remaining  sections  of  the  western  regional  road  is  estimated  at  $262 million, 
which  is  significantly  more  than  ADB  has  been  able  to  provide  under  a  single  loan  to  the 
transport  sector  in  Mongolia.9 At  the  same  time,  the  full  benefits  of  the  road—particularly  for 
long-distance and transit traffic and to spur new economic development opportunities—will only 
be realized once the road corridor is complete. The MFF modality allows ADB to include the full 
scope of the road under the investment program and align its financing with the government’s 
ability to implement the investment program. The MFF will allow the government to proceed as 
quickly  as  its  expanding  access  to  ADB  and  other  resources 10
 and  implementation  progress 
permit. 
 
11. 
Policy framework and road map. To play its part in the rapid expansion of Mongolia’s 
transport network, the road subsector needs capacity development and modernization. ADB has 
had  extensive  dialogue  with  the  government  to  formulate  a  sector  road  map  and  capacity 
development  strategy. 11  This  road  map  establishes  medium-  and  long-term  performance 
objectives  for  the  road  subsector  and  draws  up  a  series  of  targets  and  actions  to  be 
implemented.  To  support  the  implementation  of  priority  reforms  and  build  capacity,  ADB  has 
approved capacity development TA to be implemented in parallel with the proposed MFF. 12
 The 
TA  will  assist  the  government  to  implement  the  initial  phase  of  the  road  map.  Road  map 
implementation targets are incorporated as government undertakings for the MFF. 
 
Strategic  context.  The  investment  program  addresses  ADB’s  strategic  goals 13 in  the 
12. 
transport  sector  to  (i)  foster  regional  integration  by  reducing  transport  and  logistics  costs; 
(ii) improve  sector  institutions,  management,  human  capacity,  and  asset  sustainability;  and 
(iii) develop and improve regional and international transport corridors, including the completion 
of  corridor  4a  in  the  CAREC  transport  program.  The  investment  program  objectives  are  fully 
consistent with the strategic goals articulated in the country partnership strategy.14
 
 
13. 
Investment  program.  The  physical  elements  of  the  investment  program  include 
(i) completing  the  western  regional  road,  which  has  long  been  part  of  Mongolia’s  national 
development  strategy,  (ii)  linking  small  villages  and  towns  to  the  main  corridor  to  spread  the 
benefits of the investment to regional population centers, and (iii) establishing road maintenance 
centers  to  improve  asset  management  and  sustainability.  Nonphysical  components  include 
capacity development in the road subsector, support for local contractors, extensive on-the-job 
training in project management and implementation, and sector reform initiatives adopted in the 
road map and implemented through coordination and performance links between the MFF and

implementation will provide strong incentives for sector development and reform. 
 
14. 
Additional  financing. The phase I project now under implementation has experienced 
cost overruns as a result of price escalation, leaving one section of the road without sufficient 
financing. The government has requested additional financing for that section, through tranche 1 
of the proposed MFF. The request meets ADB’s requirements for additional financing15 through 
an  MFF. 16
 Therefore,  tranche  1  of  the  proposed  investment  program  includes  additional 
financing  to  complete  the  phase  I  project.  The  remaining  sections  of  the  phase  I  project  are 
proceeding satisfactorily. The road section receiving supplementary financing will be completed 
within 3 years of the grant closing date for phase I. The investment program remains consistent 
with the phase I project’s development objectives. 
 
B. 
 
15. 
The  impact  of  the  investment  program  will  be  inclusive  economic  growth  promoted  by 
enhanced  local  and  regional  connectivity  in  the  remote  western  region  of  Mongolia.  The 
outcome will be improved transport accessibility within the project area and between countries. 
 
C. 
 
16. 
Project  1.  Outputs  to  be  financed  under  project  1  will  be  (i) 103.3  km  of  paved  road 
constructed between Baga Ulaan Davaa and Mankhan, (ii) one maintenance center established 
and  equipped,  (iii)  20  km  of  local  access  road  constructed  between  district  centers  and  the 
western  regional  road,  and  (iv)  capacity  development  for  maintenance  planning,  and  works, 
procurement, and project management. 
 
17. 
Project  2.  Outputs  to  be  financed  under  project  2  are  expected  to  be  (i)  103.9  km  of 
paved  road  constructed  between  Khovd  provincial  center  and  Khashaatiin  Davaa,  (ii)  one 
maintenance  center  established  and  equipped,  (iii)  two  bridges  and  10  km  of  local  road 
rehabilitated in Khovd provincial center, between the western regional road and the airport, and 
(iv) additional and ongoing support for capacity development and reform in the road subsector, 
which will be identified in the TA (footnote 12). 
 
18. 
Project  3. Outputs to be financed under project 3 are expected to be (i) 44 km of road 
between  Khashaatiin  Davaa  and  Buraatiin  Davaa,  16  km  of  paved  road  constructed  between 
Buraatiin Davaa and Tolbo District, and 25.8 km of paved road constructed between Tsaganuur 
and Ulaanbayshint; (ii) one maintenance unit established and equipped; (iii) one bridge and 4.9 
km of local road rehabilitated in Olgiy provincial center, linking to the western regional road; and 
(iv) additional and ongoing support for capacity development and reform in the road subsector, 
which will be finalized during the implementation of the work under project 2.

4 

 

 Special Features 

D. 
 
19. 
Previous  externally  financed  road  construction  projects,  including  those  supported  by 
ADB, have relied on foreign contractors for civil works, limiting the development of the local road 
contracting  industry.  A  viable  local  road  contracting  industry  is  essential  to  ensure  that  the 
country has the capacity to maintain the existing and planned roads, as well as to support new 
construction.  The  MFF  provides  an  opportunity  to  raise  the  capacity  and  quality  of  local  road 
contractors so that they can produce an increasing share of road construction work and play a 
leading role in the ongoing maintenance of Mongolia’s road assets. This will also ensure greater 
economic spinoffs for Mongolia as a result of the investments in road construction. 
 
20. 
Through  the  MFF,  ADB  will  prioritize  the  development  of  the  local  road  contracting 
industry in two ways: (i) civil works contracts will be packaged such that local contractors will be 
able  to  compete  under  international  competitive  bidding  procedures;  and  (ii)  by  making  future 
tranches  under  the  MFF  contingent  on  the  government  providing  adequate  budgets  for  road 
maintenance  and  upon  demonstrated  performance  of  maintenance  work,  ADB  will  promote  a 
more steady and expanding stream of work for local contractors. The parallel TA will reinforce 
these efforts by supporting the development and implementation of asset management systems 
and procedures, and by supporting human resource development, research, and training. 
 
E. 
 
21. 
The  investment  program  is  estimated  to  cost  $262  million  equivalent.  Project  1—
including  taxes,  duties,  physical  and  price  contingencies,  interest,  and  other  charges—is 
estimated to cost $72.85 million equivalent (Table 1).

agreements for each tranche, and fulfillment of terms and conditions and undertakings set forth

specifically requested flexibility in the use of ADF resources for the second and third tranches. It

corresponding  reduction  of  the  available  OCR  financing  (and  vice-versa),  so  that  the  total 
financing provided by ADB will not exceed the aggregate amount of $170 million equivalent. Any 
additional ADF allocation will be subject to (i) the general availability of ADF resources from time 
to time, (ii) Mongolia’s access to such resources pursuant to ADB’s then applicable Graduation 
Policy, 21 and  the  requirements  of  ADF  donors,  and  (iii)  the  availability  of  such  resources  to 
Mongolia pursuant to ADB’s then applicable policy on the performance-based allocation of ADF 
resources.22

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical 

24. 
The  western  regional  road  is  being  constructed  as  a  two-lane,  undivided  road  with  a 
design speed of up to 100 km per hour. The carriageway is 7 meters wide with 1.5 meter gravel 
shoulders. The existing road to be upgraded under project 1 is entirely made up of dirt tracks. 
The investment program does not have any unusual technical risks. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

25. 
The investment program is economically viable, with an estimated economic internal rate 
of  return  of  11.0%,  and  a  net  present  value  of  $19.5  million  at  a  10%  discount  rate.  The 
investment program will cut user transport costs and time by nearly 50%, ensure all-year access 
for small vehicles, and reduce travel hazards. The investment program will foster local economic 
growth and increase cross-border trade. 
 
It is ADB’s practice to consider projects with an  economic internal rate of return above 
26. 
10%,  to  be  economically  justified  when  they  generate  significant  unquantified  economic 
benefits. 24
 For  the  investment  program,  these  benefits  include  (i)  increased  accessibility  to 
education and health facilities for rural herders; (ii) easier mitigation and relief of weather-related 
emergencies in rural areas; and (iii) scale economies, stronger competition, and agglomeration 

                                                 
24 ADB. 2003. Economic Analysis of Projects. Operations Manual. OM G1/OP. Manila. 

7 

 

 for  road  maintenance 

benefits generated by the improved accessibility of western Mongolia. The investment program 
will also promote poverty relief and improved equity, as (i) it will improve the farm-gate value of 
the  meat,  wool,  and  dairy  products  sold  by  poor  herders;  (ii)  it  will  create  low-skilled  job 
opportunities  during  construction  and 
in  an  area  of  chronic 
underemployment;  and  (iii) it  will  enhance  gender  equity  by  creating  new  opportunities  for 
women herders to generate income, by reducing the time they spend going to market and taking 
children  to schools  or hospitals.  The  investment  program  will  also  help  redistribute  Mongolia’s 
economic activity toward its poorest rural areas and foster national integration.  
 
27. 
ADB  is  implementing  several  social  development  projects  in  western  Mongolia,  which 
will complement the investment program and help to spread the benefits of the western regional 
road to the poor. These include the Education for the Poor—Financial Crisis Response Project; 
Early  Childhood  Education  for  Rural,  Nomadic,  and  Migrant  Children;  and  the  Food  and 
Nutrition, Social Welfare Program and Project.25
 
 
28. 
The  investment  program  will  not  earn  any  direct  revenue.  Maintenance  of  the  roads 
constructed  under  the  investment  program  will  be  funded  from  central  government  allocations 
collected from fuel taxes and general revenue allocations. 
 
C. 

Governance 

29. 
All works and goods to be financed under the MFF will be procured in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). All consulting services to 
be financed under the MFF will be procured in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The procurement plan has been drafted and 
agreed  with  the  government  and  is  included  as  an  appendix  to  the  facility  administration 
manual.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and 
discussed with the government. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the facility administration manual.

under the investment program.
